panels.title: Instance Information & Settings
panels.description: Core PostgreSQL configuration and status. Monitor version, uptime, and critical settings.

panels.title: Version
panels.description: PostgreSQL version. Goal: Stay current with latest stable versions for security and performance. Action: Plan upgrades annually, test in staging first.

panels.title: Uptime
panels.description: Database uptime in days. Goal: High uptime with planned maintenance windows. Action: If uptime is very low, investigate recent crashes or restarts.

panels.title: Max Connections
panels.description: Maximum allowed connections from postgresql.conf. Goal: Right-sized for workload. Action: If nearing limit, increase max_connections or implement connection pooling (PgBouncer).

panels.title: Autovacuum
panels.description: Autovacuum enabled status (1=on, 0=off). Goal: Always enabled. Action: If off, enable immediately to prevent bloat and wraparound.

panels.title: Fsync
panels.description: Fsync enabled status (1=on, 0=off). Goal: Always enabled for data durability. Action: Never disable in production - data loss risk.

panels.title: Shared Buffers
panels.description:
PostgreSQL shared buffer pool size in bytes.

GOAL: 25-40% of system RAM for dedicated servers
- Too low: Poor cache hit ratio, high disk I/O
- Too high: Less RAM for OS cache, can hurt performance

ACTIONS TO IMPROVE:
1. Increase shared_buffers if cache hit ratio is low
2. Monitor pg_stat_bgwriter for buffer allocation
3. Balance with effective_cache_size setting
4. For 16GB RAM: set shared_buffers = 4-6GB

panels.title: Critical Alerts - Connection Pool & Performance
panels.description: Key metrics requiring immediate attention when thresholds exceeded.

Connection pool utilization ratio (0.0-1.0). Shows how close PostgreSQL is to running out of connections.

GOAL: Stay below 70% utilization during normal operation
- < 0.7 (70%): Healthy
- 0.7-0.8: Monitor closely, plan capacity increase
- > 0.8: Critical - take immediate action

ACTIONS TO IMPROVE:
1. Implement connection pooling (PgBouncer, Pgpool-II)
2. Reduce application connection pool sizes
3. Increase max_connections (requires RAM)
4. Fix connection leaks (check idle_age metrics)
5. Enable idle_in_transaction_session_timeout

KUBERNETES TIP: max_connections >= (num_pods x connections_per_pod) + 20% buffer

panels.title: Connection Pool Status

panels.description:
PostgreSQL performance degrades with **100+ ACTIVE connections**, regardless of max_connections setting.

**Common K8s Problem:**
- Pods autoscale -> connection pools multiply
- Result: Massive IDLE connections flooding the database
- Even with low active, total connections exhaust resources

**What to watch:**
- ACTIVE = Actual queries running (alert when >100)
- IDLE = Wasted connections from pod scaling
- IDLE IN TRANSACTION = Critical (holding locks)

**Solution:** Use PgBouncer for connection pooling in K8s

**Alert on:** Active > 100, NOT percentage utilization!

panels.description:
Maximum transaction and query duration across all connections.

GOAL: No queries running >5 minutes (adjust for workload)
- Long transactions: Block vacuum, cause bloat
- Long queries: May indicate missing indexes or inefficient SQL

ACTIONS TO IMPROVE:
1. Identify long queries: SELECT pid, now() - xact_start, query FROM pg_stat_activity WHERE state = 'active' ORDER BY xact_start;
2. Add missing indexes (use EXPLAIN)
3. Optimize query logic
4. Set statement_timeout = 30s (adjust per workload)
5. Monitor for blocking queries

METRICS: Max transaction duration, max query duration
panels.title: Long-Running Queries

panels.description:
Active connections by wait event type.

GOAL: Understand what database is waiting on
- Lock: Blocking queries, tune application
- IO: Slow disk, increase shared_buffers
- Client: Application not reading results fast
- CPU: Heavy processing, optimize queries

ACTIONS TO IMPROVE:
1. Lock waits: Enable log_lock_waits, reduce transaction time
2. IO waits: Add indexes, increase shared_buffers, faster storage
3. Client waits: Fix slow applications reading data
4. Check pg_stat_activity for wait_event details

QUERY: SELECT wait_event_type, wait_event, count(*) FROM pg_stat_activity WHERE wait_event IS NOT NULL GROUP BY 1,2;

panels.description:
Checkpoint frequency and timing.

REQUIRES: PostgreSQL 17+ (uses pg_stat_checkpointer)
For PostgreSQL 16 and earlier, this panel will show no data.

GOAL: Checkpoints spread evenly, meeting checkpoint_completion_target
- Too frequent: Tune checkpoint_timeout, increase max_wal_size
- Too slow: Increase shared_buffers

ACTIONS TO IMPROVE:
1. Tune checkpoint_timeout (5min-30min typical)
2. Set checkpoint_completion_target = 0.9
3. Increase max_wal_size for write-heavy workloads
4. Monitor checkpoint_warning in logs
5. Balance I/O load distribution

METRICS: Timed vs requested checkpoints (from pg_stat_checkpointer)

panels.description:
WAL archiving status (if configured).

GOAL: All archives successful, no failures
- Failed archives: Check archive_command
- Growing failed count: Storage or network issues

ACTIONS TO IMPROVE:
1. Verify archive_command is correct
2. Check archive destination has space
3. Test network connectivity to archive location
4. Monitor archive_status directory growth
5. Set archive_timeout for streaming

METRICS: Archived count vs failed count

panels.title: Vacuum & Maintenance
panels.description: Autovacuum effectiveness and table bloat monitoring. Critical for preventing bloat and wraparound.

Vacuum progress by table (0-100%). Shows the percentage of heap blocks scanned during active vacuum operations.

This metric tracks ongoing VACUUM operations and helps identify:
- Long-running vacuum processes that may need attention
- Progress of manual or autovacuum operations
- Tables currently undergoing maintenance

METRIC: pg_vacuum_heap_progress (0.0-1.0 ratio)
- 0.0 = Just started (0%)
- 0.5 = Half complete (50%)
- 1.0 = Fully scanned (100%)

LABEL: table = schema.table name (e.g., public.users)

Note: Only shows data when a VACUUM operation is actively running. When no vacuum is active, shows "none" with value 0.
panels.title: Vacuum Progress

panels.description: Number of heap blocks vacuumed during active vacuum operations. This metric shows the absolute count of 8KB heap blocks that have been vacuumed. Higher values indicate more aggressive vacuum activity, which may correlate with: - High table bloat - Frequent UPDATE/DELETE operations - Autovacuum threshold being reached Note: This is a point-in-time metric during active vacuum operations. Use in conjunction with 'Vacuum Progress' to understand vacuum efficiency. Formula: heap_blks_vacuumed from pg_stat_progress_vacuum
panels.title: Heap Blocks Vacuumed

panels.description:
WAL generation and buffer allocation rates.

GOAL: Steady pattern, no sudden spikes
- High WAL: Write-heavy workload
- Buffer allocation: Shared buffers turnover

ACTIONS TO IMPROVE:
1. Increase shared_buffers if buffer allocation high
2. Tune checkpoint_completion_target
3. Monitor wal_buffers
4. Adjust wal_writer_delay
5. Consider archiving/replication impact

METRIC: bytes/second
panels.title: WAL & Buffer Activity

panels.description:
Background writer cleaning dirty buffers.

GOAL: Proactive cleaning before backends need pages
- High bgwriter clean rate: Good
- High backend writes: Increase bgwriter activity

ACTIONS TO IMPROVE:
1. Tune bgwriter_lru_maxpages
2. Adjust bgwriter_lru_multiplier
3. Reduce bgwriter_delay
4. Monitor buffer allocation patterns

METRIC: Buffers cleaned per second
panels.title: Background Writer Activity
Replication & WAL (requires --collector.replication)
panels.description: Replication lag and WAL generation. Monitor replica health and streaming replication status.

Rate of INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE operations per second.

 REQUIRES: --collector.stat flag to be enabled

GOAL: Monitor for patterns, optimize high-activity tables
- High INSERT rate: Consider bulk loading, COPY
- High UPDATE rate: May cause bloat, check HOT updates
- High DELETE rate: Triggers vacuum, monitor bloat

ACTIONS TO IMPROVE:
1. Batch operations when possible
2. Use COPY instead of INSERT for bulk data
3. Enable HOT updates (avoid updating indexed columns)
4. Partition high-activity tables
5. Tune autovacuum for write-heavy tables
6. Monitor table_size growth

WHY SHOWING 'No Data':
1.  --collector.stat NOT enabled (most common cause)
2. No write activity in selected databases
3. Check database filter ($database variable)
4. Metrics are rate(counter[5m]) - needs sustained activity over 5 minutes

TO FIX: Start pg_exporter with --collector.stat flag
panels.title: Table DML Operations Rate
Table Statistics (requires --collector.stat)
panels.description: Table-level DML activity and statistics. Identify hot tables and optimization candidates. REQUIRES --collector.stat flag.

Total size of each database in bytes.

GOAL: Monitor growth trends, plan capacity
- Sudden growth: investigate unexpected data
- Steady growth: normal, plan storage scaling

ACTIONS TO IMPROVE:
1. Identify large tables (pg_total_relation_size)
2. Archive old data
3. Partition large tables
4. Drop unused indexes
5. Run VACUUM FULL on bloated tables (maintenance window)
6. Consider table compression (TOAST settings)
panels.title: Database Size

panels.description:
Database size change rate in bytes/sec.

GOAL: Predictable, steady growth
- Spikes: Investigate bulk loads or bloat
- Negative: VACUUM FULL or DROP operations

ACTIONS TO IMPROVE:
1. Implement data retention policies
2. Archive historical data
3. Monitor autovacuum effectiveness
4. Plan storage capacity 6-12 months ahead
5. Use partitioning for time-series data
panels.title: Database Growth Rate
Database Size & Growth (requires --collector.database)
panels.description: Database and table size trends. Plan capacity and identify growth patterns.

Cumulative total of index scans since PostgreSQL started.

GOAL: Should be steadily increasing
- Growing: Indexes are being used
- Flat/zero: Unused indexes (candidates for removal)

ACTIONS TO IMPROVE:
1. Identify tables with high sequential scans
2. Analyze query patterns with EXPLAIN
3. Create missing indexes for tables with seq scans
4. Drop unused indexes to reduce write overhead

NOTE: This is a cumulative counter, not a rate. Resets on PostgreSQL restart. Enable --collector.index to get this metric.
panels.title: Total Index Scans

panels.description:
Total size of all user indexes in bytes.

GOAL: Monitor index storage usage
- Growing: Normal with data growth
- Large size: May indicate bloat or unused indexes

ACTIONS TO IMPROVE:
1. Identify and drop unused indexes
2. REINDEX bloated indexes (maintenance window)
3. Review duplicate or redundant indexes
4. Monitor after index changes

NOTE: This is an aggregate metric. Enable --collector.index to get this metric.
panels.title: Total Index Size
Index Performance & Unused Indexes (requires --collector.index)
panels.description: Index usage statistics and unused index detection. Optimize by adding missing indexes and dropping unused ones.

CPU usage of pg_exporter process.

**Per-Core %** (Left Y-Axis, solid line):
- Actual CPU usage (matches ps, top, pidstat)
- Can exceed 100% on multi-core systems
- Example: 124% = using 1.24 cores worth of CPU

**Normalized %** (Right Y-Axis, dashed line):
- Per-core average (cpu_percent / cpu_cores)
- Always 0-100% range
- Shows average CPU load per core
- Example: 124% / 24 cores = 5.17% per-core

**Typical values (per-core %):**
- Idle: 1-5%
- Light load: 5-15%
- Moderate: 15-30%
- Heavy: 30-50%

**Note:** First reading after startup will be 0% (sysinfo needs 2 refreshes for accuracy).
panels.title: Exporter Process CPU Usage

panels.description:
Memory usage of the pg_exporter process.

**RSS (Resident Set Size):** Actual physical RAM used by the process
- What's counted: Code, stack, heap, shared libraries actively in RAM
- This is the "real" memory usage you care about

**VSZ (Virtual Size):** Total virtual memory allocated
- Includes: RSS + swapped memory + memory-mapped files + shared libraries
- Usually 2-10x larger than RSS (this is normal!)
- Example: RSS=45MB, VSZ=500MB is typical

**GOAL:** Stable RSS over time (no memory leaks)

**ACTIONS IF RSS INCREASING:**
1. Check for memory leaks in exporter
2. Reduce number of collectors or databases monitored
3. Check metric cardinality explosion (see Total Metrics panel)
4. Review connection pool settings

**NOTE:** VSZ growth is usually harmless - focus on RSS trends
panels.title: Exporter Memory Usage

panels.description:
Number of open file descriptors.

GOAL: Stay well below system limit (usually 1024 or ulimit -n)

WARNING: If this approaches the limit, the exporter will fail with 'too many open files'

ACTIONS IF HIGH:
1. Check for file descriptor leaks
2. Increase ulimit if needed
3. Review database connection pooling
panels.title: Open File Descriptors

panels.description:
Collector health timeline showing scrape status over time.

**GREEN** = Scraping successfully
**RED** = Failed scrape

**LEGEND SHOWS:**
- Collector name
- Current status (hover for details)

**WHAT TO LOOK FOR:**
- Red bars = Failed scrapes (check logs immediately)
- Gaps = Collector not running/enabled
- Flapping (red/green/red) = Intermittent issues

**ACTIONS IF RED:**
1. Check pg_exporter logs for error details
2. Verify database connectivity and permissions
3. Check required extensions (pg_stat_statements, etc.)
4. Review collector-specific requirements

**TIP:** Pair with 'Collector Scrape Duration' panel on right to see if slow collectors correlate with failures
panels.title: Collector Health Timeline

panels.description:
Time spent collecting metrics from PostgreSQL per collector.

GOAL: < 1 second per collector

Use to identify slow collectors.
panels.title: Collector Scrape Duration

panels.description:
Time elapsed since each collector last successfully scraped.

**GOAL:** < 60 seconds (should match scrape interval)

**GREEN:** Recent scrape (< 60s)
**YELLOW:** Delayed (60-120s)
**RED:** Stale/stuck (> 120s)

**SHOWS:**
- Which collectors are running on schedule
- Which collectors are stuck/stale
- How long since last successful collection

**ACTIONS IF HIGH:**
1. Check if collector is enabled
2. Look for errors in Health Timeline above
3. Check Scrape Duration on right for slow collectors
4. Review pg_exporter logs
panels.title: Time Since Last Scrape

panels.description:
Total number of metrics currently exported by pg_exporter.

GOAL: Keep cardinality under your monitoring platform limits
- Cortex/Mimir: Often have strict series limits
- Prometheus: High cardinality = high memory usage

ACTIONS IF TOO HIGH:
1. Disable unnecessary collectors
2. Filter databases (use PG_EXPORTER_EXCLUDE_DATABASES)
3. Review metric labels for high cardinality
4. Check for label explosion (many tables/databases)

title: PostgreSQL Monitoring Dashboard
description: PostgreSQL Performance Monitoring Dashboard This dashboard provides comprehensive monitoring for PostgreSQL databases using pg_exporter metrics. KEY SECTIONS: - Instance Information: PostgreSQL version, settings, and uptime - Critical Alerts: Connection pool utilization and performance warnings - Connection Analysis: Active connections, idle transactions, and connection age - Query Performance: Top queries by execution time, calls, and I/O (requires pg_stat_statements extension) - Cache & I/O: Buffer cache hit ratios, shared buffers, and I/O operations - Locks & Blocking: Lock monitoring and blocking query detection - Vacuum & Maintenance: Autovacuum activity, table bloat, and maintenance statistics - Replication & WAL: Replication lag and WAL generation (if replication is configured) - Table Statistics: DML operations and table-level activity - Database Size: Database growth and size trends REQUIREMENTS: - PostgreSQL 12+ recommended - pg_stat_statements extension enabled for query performance metrics - Appropriate monitoring user permissions For more information, visit: https://github.com/nbari/pg_exporter
